comments.text_original:
Everyone who goes racing themselves knows what a ridiculous rulebook the FIA has. And the Lawson-Sainz incident is a prime example of why one rule needs to change.
Needing to be ahead of the car you're overtaking before the corner to even be entitled to some space is nothing short of crazy.
This just makes overtaking, especially around the outside, impossible and it acts as if there is no space for two cars going side by side through a corner. 
What a shame, as these kind of overtakes are the most impressive imo.
Well, I guess we can finally say goodbye to the "all the time you have to leave a space" and finally accept drivers throwing their car into the apex first and running the other car off the track.
One easy improvement would be to go from "the overtaking car needs to be in front by the apex to be entitled to some space" to "the overtaking car needs to be significantly alongside by the apex to be entitled to at least a car's width of space" 
"Significantly alongside" would mean the front axle needs to be at least alongside the rear axle of the other car.
What do you guys think of this?
